If I Close My Eyes You Can't See Me

Carrie On | 25 September 2024

A young man in Ohio was shocked to discover his Mom and Grandma had been witness to his inappropriate online behavior. Forgetting how everyone you have in your friendship circle is inextricably connected on social media, he didn't hold back when trying to chat up the girls. Remember adding family when you first signed up to Facebook? He didn't. Not having communicated through that media from day one, their presence must have slipped his mind.

He is not the only one to fall foul of this oversight, many users think they are wearing an invisibility cloak when it comes to online communication. Members of groups aren't checking to see if these groups are public, private or closed. Imagine the horror when one young lady got a comment in a dating group instructing her to 'put her clothes on' and wash, '...all that muck off your face.' It was her Father.

It works the other way round as well. Parents getting pulled up by their kids. Childless couples tagging their friends on social media after a raucous party the kids had no idea they'd been to. No-one wants to see a pic of dad kissing mom. Whatever age you are.

If you want to survive your social media experience without the embarrassment of getting caught out by your boss, family, or elderly aunts and uncles, whatever you post ask yourself would you be happy if everyone you know read it?

If you want privacy in your life pick up a pen and write a letter. Unless you're in a correctional institution nobody is ever going to read that. Or how about a phone call?

The next time your kid shouts at you, 'You poke your nose into everything I do, I'm entitled to a private life.' Remind them just because you can share your life with the world online, doesn't mean you have to. You're not the one poking your nose in.

New Year - New Friends

Grace O'Gawd | 27 September 2024

It's always the same. A new year begins and those people you thought were your friends go, well, a bit weird. Your nearest and dearest, between them, have a very long list of things they want to change about themselves. I liked them just the way they were, that's why we were friends in the first place. January only used to embrace two life changes. Cessation. Smoking and eating. Now everything has a 'uary' slapped on the end of it, January is the new 'Mis-uary'.

? DRY JANUARY - does not reflect the current weather. This is where one undertakes a month of not drinking anything alcoholic. The friends who succeed in this are smug, patronizing and are heading for a 14 lbs weight loss as an added bonus. That is assuming they were a big drinker in the first place. The smuggest of all are the ones who only ever drank on high days and holidays, and there aren't any of those in January. Therefore, they are bound to succeed. Statistics show abstention leads to bingeing. Bring on March when they've put on 28 lbs. Who's smug now?

? VEGANUARY - As much as I don't have a problem with becoming vegan as a life choice, I do object to the way my nice, mild-mannered, buddies become activists overnight. Suddenly they're not free for a nice Sunday afternoon stroll, they have plans to storm the nearest store and shout at people who so much as eye up a juicy steak. Social media is flooded with videos and memes, selfies of my mates snuggled up to livestock, making new friends who share their values and beliefs. I am reminded my friendship is hanging by a thread as I have not joined the V-Gang. I do not want to be around them on the 1st February when they revert to their carnivore ways.

Shopping Woes

Peg Up | 29 September 2024

I'm one of those really annoying people you don't want to get stuck behind in the grocery store. I love to chat, and boy can I chat, to the cashier. My money is always at the bottom of my rucksack, and I have to do up four buckles when I've finished so I have two free hands to carry my bags.

Recently there was a lady behind me who had a face that clearly indicated a personality lacking any patience, or compassion even. If everything I mentioned above wasn't enough to make her face turn milk sour, I had a $50 bill. If you present a $50 bill in a store bells ring, announcements are made requesting the dollar bills inspector comes to the checkout, and security hovers in your path guarding the exit. Depending on how quickly the dollar bills inspector makes his/her way to you, this can add another 5-10 minutes of waiting.

On that particular day, the dollar bills inspector was on sick leave. The person designated to take this role in their absence had forgotten it was his job for the day. Eventually, with much scurrying around, and loud whispering, he finally made it to the till. He spent several minutes holding the bill up to the light, crumpling it, stretching it out and mumbling inaudible comments. Finally, the cashier reminded him he needed to take it to the kiosk so it could be viewed under ultraviolet light.

On his return, my bill was given a glowing report, was legal tender and could be used to purchase the items on the belt. I turned and apologized to misery face behind me. She deliberately turned her head away in disgust and spoke loudly to the gentleman standing behind her. She said something about how she had aged during this process, and 'some people' and had other silly little negative digs at me. I was too afraid to take the time to say thank you to the lovely young lady on the checkout and hurried away with my tail between my legs.

There is, and was, a very important lesson to learn through this experience. A few days later I was at the dentist, anxious as per usual, waiting for the big scary drill to fill a gaping hole. Who should I look up and see? My new dentist, and it was her! Misery face from the grocery store. So the moral is, be careful who you annoy when out shopping. Or doing anything for that matter.

Lies, Lies & More Lies

Bart Gallery | 30 September 2024

I remember the first time I told a lie. That's not to say I didn't do it before then, I just don't remember. I was nine years old and at my third school already. Fitting into already established friendship groups was hard. So on that dreaded Monday morning when we had to sit and write about what we did over the weekend I made up a great big fat lie in the hope of making myself an interesting person. I told the class the window cleaner had fallen off his ladder. This is when I learned lies don't get you anywhere. Nobody liked me any the more for it, it did not dramatically transform my world into a better one.

I have a book on my desk called 'Lying', my son suggested I read it as telling lies has always been a big topic of conversation. The types of lies we tell. He insists that even though I don't think I tell lies, I get creative with the truth. Should someone call I don't want to speak to, but for some reason, the phone must be answered? I will tell him to say I'm in the bath. I will then go and stand in the bath so that I am at ease with my conscience. I have not told a lie, I am in the bath.

People always say it's OK to tell 'little white lies', if it is in the best interest of the person being little-white-lied to. Recently I mentioned to an (almost) total stranger that I had lost 14lbs in weight. He replied, 'I thought you had, I noticed that.' When I got all excited and started pulling my stomach in and preening myself he added, 'I didn't really, I just know the right things to say.' I ask you, what kind of perverse lie is that?

In society we grade our lies; the little white one, a great big fat one, a fib (equal to the little white lie) but all lies have consequences. Imagine if it had turned out that someone in my class knew my window cleaner, saw him up a ladder on the way home from school and called up to ask if he was OK after his fall. He could have been startled, dropped his bucket on the child and have proceeded to actually fall off his ladder. In my fantasies, it would have been the most popular girl with the long blonde hair who got hit by the bucket. I'm sure she was lovely really.

You know the biggest question of all time, 'does my butt look big in this?' In an effort to be kind, and not get a punch on the nose, the answer is nearly always, 'no.' My favorite response has to be, 'your butt doesn't look big in just 'this', it looks big in everything because you have a big butt.' I think there would be a small number of people who could get away with that. But if you tell someone their butt doesn't look big, but it really does, how are you helping them? What if as a result of that lie they book a long-haul flight but aren't aware they need a larger than the standard seat to accommodate that big butt? They arrive at Disneyland, Florida, spend 3 hours queuing for a ride their butt is too large to sit in, all that waiting for nothing. Holiday ruined.

In conclusion, I suggest you think twice before telling a lie of any size. Because contrary to belief, size does really matter.

The Lies People Tell

Cindy Music | 01 October 2024

The best kind of lies are the ones you overhear other people telling. You know they are lying because you're standing in a bar when you hear them on the phone saying, 'I'm in the grocery store.' At times like this I have an overwhelming urge to run up to them, and loudly report their room is ready, or 'it's your round'.

For some people lying comes very easy. Some people will even tell a lie before they tell the truth. Once you're caught out in a lie it'll be hard for anyone to trust you again, so why do it? But then, what kind of place would the world be if we all told the truth? It would be a tough one I'm sure.

As an insecure, and overly sensitive person, I appreciate the lies, or comforting untruths people tell me. Getting a short haircut you really hate, which looks absolutely terrible, needs the words, 'I like your hair short', It means they like your hair short, but not at that precise moment. Very clever that one, and I'm more than happy to take that. It is a useful tool for all responses, 'dresses really suit you', but clearly not the one you are wearing. The one that throws me is when someone says they like your crazy boots, and wish they had the courage to wear something like that. I then think other people are staring at me and I'm wearing something totally inappropriate.

Then you get the people who tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth. These people scare me half to death. This is the only time I advocate the telling of lies, chuck them all my way, please. These people aren't even responding to questions, the last thing you want to do is ask these people any questions of a personal nature at all. They freely, without prompting, offer up their opinions about how you look, what you wear, and every word that comes out of your mouth. These people should be avoided at all costs if you ever want to leave the house again and not feel like a sack of potatoes, they are toxic to the very core.

The moral of the story, if there is one, is about balance. What some people like to call, 'white lies'. The gentle untruths that spare people's feelings, and make them happy, or happier than they were when you first ask them that potentially explosive question, 'Do you like my new boots?'

The Hearing Test

Cindy Music | 02 October 2024

A couple of months ago my flatmate went to have his hearing tested. We all thought he was just ignoring us, but as it turned out he was struggling to keep up with the conversations and decided better to be safe than sorry. When he came back he looked so down I guessed he must have received some bad news. He went into his room and started playing incredibly loud music and didn't come out again until the evening.

I just pottered about and waited for him to tell me what was wrong. Eventually, he opened up to me and I listened preparing to be sympathetic and ready with a great big bear hug. What he told me didn't get him a hug, it got him a bellyful of laughs from me. It turns out there is a huge range of gadgets to compliment hearing aids, all wireless with blue teeth.

John, not his real name, was actually upset because he didn't need a hearing aid, his ears just needed a good old-fashioned syringe. The reason he was disappointed is that he fancied a collection of 21st Century gadgets that none of his friends have. 'You can put a dongle in the back of the television and the sound is delivered through your hearing aid.' He informed me. 'They have little remote controls to adjust the volume as well.' 'You can do everything on your smartphone.' He had even tried to trick the test by not clicking the button when he heard the beep. Apparently, they have a form of technology, similar to a lie detector test, that means you can't beat the machine.

I asked him why he had been playing his music so loud all day. John told me he was trying to make himself deaf! The lengths some people will go to be a gadget trendsetter.

Trying To Save The World

Dan Wefixit | 02 October 2024

But I Can't ...

I gave up eating meat when I was a teenager, it wasn't hard, I didn't do it for the animals I just couldn't stand the chewing process. Fast forward 20 years and my boyfriend persuaded me to try a piece of steak, 'It will melt in your mouth.' he told me. He was right, it did and it tasted great. Turns out my mum was just a really, really bad cook!

My new lease of life as a carnivore started taking shape, sausages, bacon, sausages in bacon...I ate it all. Then along came Social Media. It turned out I knew too many vegetarians and Vegans on Facebook, the videos just kept coming and coming, pigs, cows, sheep, all sad and not wanting to die. After one particularly disturbing piggy video, I put down my knife and fork and started grazing on some salad leaves.

I was back to being a proper vegetarian, it was fine, I'd done it before and I could do it again, any temptation soon evaporated when I thought of that poor little piggy. But then the Vgang upped their game, it all became about dairy, baby calves being taken from their mothers, dairy cows crying as they were taken away. It all became too much and I took the step and became a vegan. Being a vegan is very hard, no matter what the plant-based eating brigade tell you.

The worst thing about finding some vegan edibles was to then discover they contain palm oil, right at the time everyone was up in arms about palm oil. I could no longer go food shopping without my glasses and a list of meat, fish, eggs, dairy, palm oil free products. I didn't have to worry too much about plastic packaging or buying plastic bags as I had nothing to put in them anyway.

I didn't eat vegan cheese despite being a big cheese eater, because it is disgusting. So after two weeks dairy free I imploded and ordered the cheesiest pizza on the menu. This is what happens when you deprive yourself of something you enjoy, you binge on it when you fall off the wagon. So I started eating cheese again but stuck to the other changes. THEN it became about my make-up, was it cruelty-free? My clothes, shoes, bedding, towels, curtains, cushion covers, china, cutlery pretty much anything you come into contact in daily life. Who made it? What conditions do they work in? How old are they? How much do they get paid?

Ultimately I learned the only way I could save the animals, save the children, and save the planet would be to lay naked in a field in the middle of nowhere and eat nothing!

Passwords

Nick O'Time | 04 October 2024

There are three types of password users in the world; those who remember them, those who don't, and those who write them down.

Those who don't remember them, but don't write them down tend to use the same passwords for every site they need to log in to. We are told this is not great for our online security, they break one and they have them all. I'm not sure they'd want to fraudulently purchase goods from the sites I'm signed up to unless they can't afford to buy their own dog food or they want to know how to make a vegan mousse.

If we have different passwords for everything then we are forced to write them down, then you just need to add one burglar and one PC and your online banking and card details are there for them in one neat little package. I've tried hiding the book, but couldn't remember where, let's face it, it's always going to be in the vicinity of the home computer or they'd be no point having it.

Cellphones and tablets now have this smart technology where you can use fingerprint or eyeball recognition. These do not sit well with me. Firstly, I like to keep my screen clean, and therefore don't want to add extra smudges every time I need to wake it up from its premature sleep that there seem to be no settings to change. Secondly, I don't want to be sitting in a bar staring into my cell's camera, everyone will think I'm taking a close up selfie of my eyeball. Or I'm just a little bit odd.

The worst thing about setting passwords is how secretive the companies are about what they'd like from you. You happily enter the password you use for everything, a pop up tells you you need to have at least one upper case letter. Why don't they list their requirements in advance? It doesn't stop there, pop-ups all over the place; one special character, 2 numbers, the first number you thought of take away 6, get the idea?

So you now have this complicated password you will never remember as it doesn't include your dog's name or your child's date of birth. I've been caught out in this way, this is when I will reach for my pen and notepad and write the alien password in the incorrect order using a code I've only just made up. When I have then gone to use the password again in three months time I don't remember the code.

At least I know the login details for my online banking are secure, I can't even get that right most of the time. If I don't use my fingers to count when selecting any characters over 4 it's always wrong, I panic if it requests a character over 10. Recently it's been pretty kind to me, maybe they know. Probably some algorithm that counts how many login errors I've made when the questions got too difficult.

Passwords, can't live with them, can't live without them.

Volunteering

Bud Weisser | 04 October 2024

It is perhaps fair to say that volunteering conjures up feelings of helping those in need or taking time out of your own life to give back to society, family or friends. However, what often goes unspoken is that to many, volunteering means unpaid labour. The lines have been blurred in recent years with graduates forced to do endless apprenticeships and internships for 'experience', but many corporations are just using those desperate to work in certain fields for free graft, because grubby students will fall for anything after all.

It feels that there is a certain stigma attached to the word volunteering among some people. As much as we probably hate to admit it, the word doesn't evoke much excitement and truthfully, many people are put off by it. In turbulent times, there is a tend to lean more towards safe guarding our own wellbeing, but whatever the negative connotations, volunteering benefits absolutely everyone involved.

If you're thinking of a new hobby or just dusting off the yoga mat to start up an old one, have a think about whether you'd like to volunteer. The selfless deed of volunteering is the first great reason to be excited about it. Secondly, it has been proven to help people meet new friends, combat anxiety and depression, stimulate your mind and even advance your career. You never know what you're going to get out of volunteering, and the best thing about it is that it's entirely within your own control. You can decide how much or how little you do. In a world where Tinder lets you pick and choose people at break neck speed, maybe taking a step back into real life to make some organic connections is what you're after. Perhaps that nagging voice of wanting to snap at your boss and or children is getting even louder and you want a positive way to release stress, volunteering could be the thing to clear your head.

Volunteering is also an ideal avenue to practice and improve relationship skills, be it personal or professional. You'll discover that regularly meeting with people with similar interests and beliefs will lead to easier conversations about shared interests, or possibly pet peeves depending on your attachment to that person! There is also much to be said about volunteering as a family, showing your kids how rewarding it is to give back to people and a community will improve their mental health and outlook on life. Or, maybe you need to get your partner off the sofa and into something mindfully stimulating more often.

Whatever your reason, there is no negative aspect of volunteering. Use your spare time to improve your life and the lives of others, meet new people and boost your mental health.

The history of swigging port

I.C. Poorly | 07 October 2024

The 'discovery' of port dates back to the late Seventeenth Century when British sailors stumbled upon the drink in Portugal and then stumbled even more slowly home with several more bottles. It has been said since then that Portugal is the mother of port and that Britain is the father, which loosely translates as Portugal does all the hard work of growing and birthing the product, while Britain shows up on evenings and weekends just for the fun stuff.

Portugal was the only nation willing to sell port to Britain, with France, Spain and Italy denying their service, a policy that seems highly likely to return in the months to come. Yet, back then, it was a less dignified drink, being guzzled in wartime and making fools of whoever drank it. Not the drink someone would refuse these days as it isn't accompanied by the right cheese platter.

Come the early Nineteenth Century, the Port drinking games had begun. To truly prove yourself as a man, you first would have to complete the 'three bottle challenge', this is the ability of a young man to finish, in one sitting, three bottles of port.

But this crass challenge must have been confined to the watering holes, the taverns, the spat upon lower classes? Such low-grade behaviour would not be seen from the more elite in society until Fresher's week was invented, surely? Not so. This challenge carried with it a celebrity like badge of honour, so much so that William Pitt the Younger, the brilliant politician would be seen chugging vast amounts of port each day. Pitt was Prime Minister by 24 so who's to argue with seeing off several bottles of port each day doesn't improve someone's prospects.

However, as time has gone by and the world yearns for the days when a few bottles of port was a politician's biggest vice, port has turned into an after-dinner drink, part of a cheese course and a treat on a cold winter's night. Let us never forget the history of port and its important role in crafting drinking games and politicians. Before it was mandatory you pass the port to the left, you didn't pass the port until there was none left.
